detailedDescription.$t: This is the total number of Passing TDs in a game by a player or team.
This is the length in yards of a passing TD in a game.  This rule is evaluated for EACH passing TD in a game.

This is the total passing yardage in a game.  For individual player positions like QBs, it is the GROSS passing yardage.  For team positions like the Team Offense, this is the NET passing yardage.  The NET passing yardage is the total passing yardage minus the total sack yardage against the team.
This is the total passing yardage divided by the number of pass completions in a game.

This is the number of pass attempts in a game.  It usually applies to the QB position, but other offensive players can have a pass attempt.  For example, if a team fakes a field goal, the holder or the kicker may attempt a pass.  All pass completions, incompletions, and interceptions are considered to be pass attempts.

The is the number of pass completions in a game.  It usually applies to the QB position, but other offensive positions can also have a completion.  For example, a RB might complete a pass after a handoff from the QB.

This is the number of pass completions in a game divided by the total number of pass attempts in a game, and then multiplied by 100.  For example, if a QB completes 7 passes with 10 attempts, his completion percentage = 70.0%
This is the number of incomplete passes in a game.  This includes Interceptions.

This is the number of pass interceptions thrown by a player in a game.  Do not use this rule for individual defensive players or the team defense position.  If you want to score an interception by a defensive player or the team defense, then use the rule called "Interceptions Caught" instead.

shortDescription.$t: Number of Interceptions Thrown Returned for a TD

detailedDescription.$t: This is the number of pass interceptions that a player throws in a game that end up being Returned all the way back for a TD.  This category is only valid for offensive positions.

shortDescription.$t: Length of Interception Thrown Returned for a TD

detailedDescription.$t: This is the length in yards of a pass interception that ends up begin returned all the way back for a TD.  This category gets evaluated for EACH Interception that is Returned for a TD in a game.

This is the number of times a QB is sacked in a game.  It can also be used for team positions, like the Team Offense, to score the total number of sacks given up by a team.  Do not use this rule for individual defensive players.  If you want to score a sack by a defensive player, then use the "Sacked a QB" rule instead.
This is the total sack yards lost by a QB in a game.  It can also be used for team positions, like the Team Offense, to score the sack yards given up by the team.
This is the number of pass completions in a game that result in a gain of 20 or more yards.
This is the number of pass completions in a game that result in a gain of 30 or more yards.
This is the number of pass completions in a game that result in a gain of 40 or more yards.
This is the number of pass completions in a game that result in a gain of 50 or more yards.
This is the number of successful two point conversion passes in a game by a player.
This is the total number of Rushing TDs in a game by a player or team.
This is the length in yards of a Rushing TD.  This rule is evaluated for EACH rushing TD in a game.
This is the total rushing yardage in a game.
This is the total rushing yardage divided by the number of rush attempts in a game.
This is the number of rush attempts in a game.
This is the number of rush attempts in a game that result in a gain of 20 or more yards.
This is the number of rush attempts in a game that result in a gain of 40 or more yards.
This is the number of successful two point conversion rushes in a game by a player.
This is the total number of Receiving TDs in a game by a player or team.
This is the length in yards of a Receiving TD.  This rule is evaluated for EACH receiving TD in a game.
This is the total receiving yardage in a game.
This is the total receiving yardage divided by the number of receptions in a game.
This is the number of receptions in a game.
This is the number of times the player was targeted as the intended receiver on a passing play.
This is the number of receptions in a game that result in a gain of 20 or more yards.
This is the number of receptions in a game that result in a gain of 40 or more yards.
This is the number of successful two point conversion receptions in a game by a player.
This is the total Rushing plus Receiving Yards
This is the total Passing plus Rushing yards
This is the total yards from scrimmage.  It include Passing, Rushing, and Receiving yards.
This is the total yards.  It includes Passing, Rushing, Receiving, Punt Return, and Kickoff Return yards.
This is the Total Number of TDs scored by a player or team.  It includes all types of TDs.
This is the number of successful field goals in a game.
This is the length in yards of a successful field goal.  This rule is evaluated for EACH successful field goal in a game.
This is the number of missed field goals in a game.  This includes field goal attempts that were blocked, but not aborted attempts in which the kicker doesn't get a chance to make the kick.
This is the length in yards of a missed field goal attempt.  This rule is evaluated for EACH missed field goal in a game.
This is the total number of field goal attempts in a game.

This is the number of successful field goals divided by the total number of field goal attempts, and then multiplied by 100.  For example, if a kicker makes 2 field goals and misses 2 field goals in a game, then he has a 50% Field Goal Percentage.
This is the total number of field goal attempts in a game that a kicker had blocked.
This is the number of successful extra points in a game.
This is the number of missed extra points in a game.  This includes extra point attempts that were blocked.
This is the number of extra points attempted in a game.
This is the number of successful extra points divided by the total number of extra point attempts, and then multiplied by 100.
This is the number of extra points in a game that a kicker had blocked.
This is the number of punts in a game.  It does not include punt attempts that were blocked.
This is the GROSS punt yardage in a game.
The is the total punt yardage divided by the number of punts.
This is the number of punts that end up inside the opponent's 20 yard line.
This is the number of punts in a game that a punter had blocked by the opponent.
This is the number of punt returns in a game that are returned all the way for a TD.
This is the length in yards of a punt return TD.  This rule is evaluated for EACH punt return TD.
This is the number of punt returns in a game.
This is the total punt return yardage in a game.
This is the total punt return yardage divided by the number of punt returns.
This is the number of punt returns in a game that result in a gain of 40 or more yards.
This is the number of kickoff returns in a game that are returned all the way for a TD.
This is the length in yards of a kickoff return TD.  This rule is evaluated for EACH kickoff return TD.
This is the number of kickoff returns in a game.
This is the total kickoff return yardage in a game.
This is the total kickoff return yardage divided by the number of kickoff returns.
This is the number of kickoff returns in a game that result in a gain of 40 or more yards.

This is the total number of fumbles by a player or a team in a game.  This includes "muffs" that occur on a punt or kickoff when a player is trying to field the kick and it bounces off his chest.  This includes ALL fumbles whether they are recovered by their own team or by the opponent.  Also, this includes ALL fumbles in the entire game, whether they are on offense or defense or special teams.  So if you assign this rule to the Team Defense position, it will include the total number of fumbles by the ENTIRE team, not just fumbles by the defense.
Includes anytime a player or team fumbles while on offense.
Includes anytime a player or team fumbles while on special teams.
Includes anytime a player or team fumbles while on defense.

This is the total number of fumbles by a player or team that end up being recovered by the opponent.  It does not include fumbles that are recovered by the player's own team.  Also, this includes ALL fumbles lost in the entire game, whether they are on offense or special teams.  So if you assign this rule to the Special Teams position, it will include the total number of fumbles by the ENTIRE team, even if they occurred on offense.
Includes anytime a player or team fumbles (and the opposing team recovers) while on offense.
Includes anytime a player or team fumbles (and the opposing team recovers) while on special teams.
Includes anytime a player or team fumbles (and the opposing team recovers) while on defense.

shortDescription.$t: Number of Defensive Fumble Recovery TDs

detailedDescription.$t: This is the number of fumble recoveries that are returned all the way for a TD.  This includes any fumbles by the opponent that are returned for a TD, whether they are on defense or special teams.  It does NOT include a fumble by a player's own team that is then recovered by a player and run in for a TD.
This is the length in yards of a defensive or special teams fumble recovery TD.  This rule is evaluated for EACH fumble recovery TD in a game.

shortDescription.$t: Length of Defensive Fumble Recovery TD

detailedDescription.$t: This is the total number of fumbles that are recovered by a player or team.  This does not include fumbles by a player's own team that are then recovered by his team.  It only includes fumbles that are then recovered by the opponent.  This includes ALL fumble recoveries, whether they occurred on defense or special teams.  So if you assign this rule to the Team Defense position, it will include the total number of fumble recoveries by the ENTIRE team, even if they occurred on Special Teams.

This is the total number of fumbles that are recovered by a player or team while on defense. This stat is not updated during the games in the live stats. It is only updated after the games are finalized.

This is the total number of fumbles that are recovered by a player or team while on special teams.  This stat is not updated during the games in the live stats. It is only updated after the games are finalized.
This is the total number of yards that a player or team returned the ball after recovering a fumble that was lost by the opponent.

This is the number of fumbles lost by a player in a game that are returned all the way back for a TD by the other team.  For example, if a running back fumbles the ball and it ends up being recovered by the opponent and returned for a TD on the same play.  This includes fumbles that are lost on offense or on special teams.

shortDescription.$t: Number of Fumbles Lost Returned for a TD

detailedDescription.$t: This is the length in yards of a lost fumble that ends up being returned all the way back for a TD by the opposing.  This rule is evaluated for EACH lost fumble that ends up being returned for a TD in a game.

shortDescription.$t: Length of Lost Fumble Returned for a TD

detailedDescription.$t: This is the number of fumble recoveries that are returned all the way for a TD after an offensive fumble by someone on the same NFL team. This includes fumbles that are recovered by a player's own team on any play from scrimmage. For example, if a Running Back fumbles at the 1 yard line right before scoring a TD, and then a Wide Receiver on the same team recovers the ball at the 1 yard line and advances to the endzone for a TD, then it is considered an Offensive fumble recovery TD.

shortDescription.$t: Number of Offensive Fumble Recovery TDs
Length of Offensive Fumble Recovery TD

detailedDescription.$t: This is the length in yards of an offensive fumble recovery that is returned all the way for a TD.  This includes fumbles that are recovered by a player's own team on any play from scrimmage. For example, if a Running Back fumbles at the 1 yard line right before scoring a TD, and then a Wide Receiver on the same team recovers the ball at the 1 yard line and advances to the endzone for a TD, then it is considered an Offensive fumble recovery TD.

This is the number of own fumble recoveries.  This ONLY includes fumbles that are recovered by a player's own team.  For example, if a Running Back fumbles at the 1 yard line right before scoring a TD, and then a Wide Receiver on the same team recovers the ball at the 1 yard line and advances to the endzone for a TD, then it is considered an Own fumble recovery TD.

This is the total yardage all offensive fumble recoveries.  This ONLY includes fumbles that are recovered by a player's own team.  For example, if a Running Back fumbles at the 5 yard line right before scoring a TD, and then a Wide Receiver on the same team recovers the ball at the 3 yard line and advances to the endzone for a TD, then it is considered 3 yards of own fumble recovery yardage.
This is the number of Forced Fumbles by a player in a game.
This is the number of interceptions in a game that are returned all the way for a TD.
This is the length in yards of an interception return TD.  This rule is evaluated for EACH interception return TD.
This is the number of interceptions by a defensive player or team defense in a game.
This is the total return yardage by a player or team after an interception.
This is the number of time a defensive player breaks up a pass, either by knocking it down or tipping it, etc.

This is the number of blocked field goals that are returned all the way for a TD.  The player that blocked the field goal is not necessarily the same player that returns it for a TD.  So one player could have a blocked field goal and another player could have a blocked field goal TD on the same play.

shortDescription.$t: Number of Blocked Field Goal TDs
Length of Blocked Field Goal TD

detailedDescription.$t: This is the length in yards of a blocked field goal TD.  This rule is evaluated for EACH blocked field goal TD.
This is the number of field goal attempts in a game that are blocked by a defensive player or a team defense position.
This is the number of missed field goals in a game that are returned all the way for a TD.

shortDescription.$t: Number of Missed Field Goal Return TDs

detailedDescription.$t: This is the length in yards of a missed field goal return TD. This rule is evaluated for EACH missed field goal return TD.

shortDescription.$t: Length of Missed Field Goal Return TD

detailedDescription.$t: This is the number of blocked punts that are returned all the way for a TD.  The player that blocked the punt is not necessarily the same player that returns it for a TD.  So one player could have a blocked punt and another player could have a blocked punt TD on the same play.
This is the length in yards of a blocked punt TD.  This rule is evaluated for EACH blocked punt TD.
This is the number of punt attempts in a game that are blocked by a defensive player or a team defense position.
This is the number of extra point attempts that are blocked by a defensive player or a team defense position.

This is the number of tackles in a game by a defensive player.  It does not include tackles by offensive players after a fumble recovery or an interception.  It also does not include tackles by players on special teams, such as on a punt or kickoff return.  Please be aware that tackles are NOT an official stat.

This is the number of assisted tackles in a game by a defensive player.  It does not include assists by offensive players after a fumble recovery or an interception.  It also does not include assists by players on special teams, such as on a punt or kickoff return.  Please be aware that tackles and assists are NOT an official stat.
This is the total number of tackles in a game by a player.  It includes tackles by an offensive player after a fumble or interception, and it includes miscellaneous tackles on special teams.
This is the total number of assisted tackles in a game by a player.  It includes assists by an offensive player after a fumble or interception, and it includes miscellaneous assists on special teams.
This is the number of sacks in a game by a defensive player or the team defense position.  Individual defensive players can have 1/2 sacks.
This is the total lost yardage of the sacks in a game by a defensive player or a team defense position.  Individual defensive players can have 1/2 yards.
This is the number of times a defensive player makes a hit on a Quarterback behind the line of scrimmage during a pass attempt. It is not updated during live scoring.
This is the number of Tackles for a Loss in a game by a defensive player. This stat is not updated during the games in the live stats. It is only updated after the games are finalized.
This is the total number of Safeties in a game by a defensive player or a team defense position.  It includes ALL safeties whether they are on defense or special teams.

This is the total points scored against a team in a game. (This matches the scoreboard points at the end of a game). If your league chooses to not include those points scored by the Defense then please see our Help Center for additional setup options.

This is the points scored against a team on Special Teams, which only includes points scored on Punt Returns and Kickoff Returns.  It also includes any conversion points scored after the TD (extra point or a 2 Pt Conversion)

This is the points scored against a team on Offense, which only includes points scored via Passing and Rushing TDs as well as Field Goals. It also includes any conversion points scored after the TDs (extra point or a 2 Pt Conversion).
This is the total yardage allowed by a team in a game.
This the total passing yardage allowed by a team in a game.
This is the total rushing yardage allowed by a team in a game.
This is the total number of TDs allowed on Special Teams, which only includes Punt Return and Kickoff Return TDs scored by the opponent.

shortDescription.$t: Number of Special Teams TDs Allowed

detailedDescription.$t: This is the total number of TDs allowed on Offense, which only includes Passing and Rushing TDs scored by the opponent.
This is the total number of Defensive TDs scored.  It includes Interception Return TDs and Opponent Fumble Recovery TDs.
This is the length in yards of a Defensive TD.  It includes Interception Return TDs and Opponent Fumble Recovery TDs.

This is the number of defensive two point conversion returns in a game.  This can be scored by blocking an extra point attempt, or by intercepting a 2-point conversion pass attempt, or by recovering a 2-point conversion fumble, and then returning it all the way to the other end zone.
This is the number of one point safeties in a game.  This can be scored on a 2-point conversion attempt by tackling the opponent in their own end zone.
This is the total number of successful two point conversions.
This is the total number of failed two point conversion attempts.

This is the number of Defensive and Special Teams TDs scored. It includes Interception Return TDs, Opponent Fumble Recovery TDs, Blocked Punt TDs, Blocked FG TDs, Punt Return TDs, Kickoff Return TDs, and Missed FG Return TDs.

shortDescription.$t: Number of Defensive & Special Teams TDs

detailedDescription.$t: This is the length in yards of a Defensive or Special Teams TD. It includes Interception Return TDs, Opponent Fumble Recovery TDs, Blocked Punt TDs, Blocked FG TDs, Punt Return TDs, Kickoff Return TDs, and Missed FG Return TDs.

This is the total number of penalties for the team or player.  It is not divided between offense and defense.  For example, if you assign this rule to the Team Defense, then they will be scored for all of the penalties by the entire team, whether they occurred on offense or defense.  Note that this stat is not updated live for individual players.
This is the total yardage lost on all of the penalties by the team or player.  Note that this stat is not updated live for individual players.
This is the time of possession in minutes for a team.
This is the total points scored by a team.

This is the difference in score between the team and the opponent.  It can be positive or zero or negative.  For example, if a team wins a game 20 to 17, then the point differential is 3.  If a team loses a game 30 to 21, then the point differential is -9 (negative 9).  This rule can be used to score a "WIN" or a "LOSS" or a "TIE" for a team position or an individual player.  A point differential of 1 or more is considered a WIN.  A point differential of -1 or less is considered a LOSS.  A point differential of 0 is a TIE.
This is the offensive points scored by a team.  It includes Passing and Rushing TDs, as well as Field Goals
This is the total number of First Downs for the team or player.
This is the number of Passing First Downs gained by the team or player.
This is the number of Rushing First Downs gained by the team or player.
This is the number of Receiving First Downs gained by the player.
This is the number of First Downs gained because of Penalties.
This is the number of successful third down conversions by the entire team.
This is the number of failed third down conversion attempts by the entire team.
This is the number of successful fourth down conversions by the entire team.
This is the number of failed fourth down conversion attempts by the entire team.
This is the number of wins a coach has.
This is the number of losses a coach has.
This is the number of ties a coach has.

shortDescription.$t: Average Passing Yards Allowed per Game
Average Rushing Yards Allowed per Game
